Name: LEAD ARSENATE
Description: Lead arsenate is an inorganic lead salt composed from lead(2+) and arsenate dianion. It was widely used in the United States in the 1950's as an insecticide to control pests in fruit orchards, specifically apples and cherries. It has a role as an insecticide, a plant growth regulator and a rodenticide. It contains a lead(2+) and an arsenate(2-).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Delistraty D, Yokel J; Environ Toxicol 29: 10-20 (2014)
plant_concentrations.Value: Mean levels of lead and arsenic detected in 11 cheatgrass samples grown at a former orchard site contaminated by the application of lead arsenate in Hanford, Washington were 12.4 and 3.9 mg/kg dry weight, respectively(1).

plant_concentrations.References: Kesterson JU et al; Hortic Sic 19 (1): 65-6 (1975) as cited in Nat'l Research Council Canada; Effects of Arsenic in the Canadian Environment p.135 (1978) NRCC No. 15391
plant_concentrations.Value: A residue of < 0.5 ppm lead arsenate was found in grapefruit oil /from plants/ grown in a hydroponic solution containing 960 ppm lead arsenate.

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Delistraty D, Yokel J; Environ Toxicol 29: 10-20 (2014)
animal_concentrations.Value: Mean levels of lead and arsenic detected in eight darkling beetle samples collected  at a former orchard site contaminated by the application of lead arsenate in Hanford, Washington were 3.9 and 5.4 mg/kg dry weight, respectively(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: Chisholm D; Can J Plant Sci 52 (4): 583-8 (1972) as cited in Nat'l Research Council Canada; Effects of Arsenic in the Canadian Environment p.108 (1978) NRCC No. 15391
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: It was noted that 16 yr after the final application of lead arsenate to a sandy soil, 54.7% of the applied arsenic remained in the soil.

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology. 3rd ed., Volumes 1-26. New York, NY: John Wiley and Sons, 1978-1984., p. V21: 280 (1983)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Arsenic residues of 440 ppm have been reported in orchard soils with a history of lead arsenate applications. ... Survey reports indicate residues of up to 2500 ppm in soils treated with lead arsenate in the 1930's.

plant_translocation.References: Miller, R. L., & Bassett, I. P. (1933). Effect of lead arsenate insecticides on orange trees in Florida (No. 1488-2016-123206).
plant_translocation.Value: Gray and Ryan observed that when acid lead arsenate was used, there was a significant reduction in acidity in the oranges, likely due to the soluble arsenic released on the foliage. Additionally, they noted that all the fruits examined from the sprayed trees showed reduced acidity. This implies that the impact of the arsenate spray on acidity was not limited to the surface of the foliage but affected the entire tree systemically, leading to changes in the fruit quality.
